text: - [Presenter] Hello everyone.
Amazon Security Lake is a security service

that automates the sourcing,
aggregation, normalization,

enrichment, and data management
of security-related data

across an entire organization
into a security data lake.

This makes the data broadly
accessible to customers

and security analytics
solutions to power use cases
such as threat detection, investigation,
and incident response.

Today, I will show you how
you can configure Splunk
as a subscriber to query the log data.
On the consumption and data access side,

Security Lake helps you
selectively share your data
with your analytic solution of choice.

You simply select the
data you want to share,
the subscriber you want to share it with,

and Security Lake manages
for you the data pipeline

and permissions required
to make it happen.
In a few clicks,
you can enable data integrations
that either require you to send new data

as it arrives or simply
provide query access

to your data so it doesn't
have to move around.
For example, to support on-demand analysis

of large volume sources
like Amazon VPC flow logs
for a security investigation.
You can decide to use your data with AWS
analytics solutions such as Amazon Athena
or Amazon SageMaker.
We've also partnered with companies

across the security
industry to make it easy

for you to use their
solutions with your data

so your security teams can
continue to use the interfaces

and workflows they are
familiar if they choose.

So I will demonstrate how
you can integrate Splunk
with Security Lake

to query security log data
in your IT environment.
In the demo, I will use Splunk add-on
for Security Lake published on Splunkbase

to configure integration
with Security Lake.

I will start with creating
a subscriber for Splunk

in Security Lake and then
connecting the subscriber
as a new input in Splunkweb.
Splunkweb is the primary interface

that you use to run
investigations, build reports,
and administer Splunk deployment.
Navigate to the Security Lake console.

Using the left hand
panel, select Subscribers.
You can see the configuration

of all subscribers in your
environment listed here.

To configure a subscriber,
select Create Subscriber.

Because we are configuring
a subscriber for Splunk,

I will name the subscriber
to reflect the same,
add a small description,
and then configure the login event sources
I would want to query using Splunk.
As I mentioned earlier,

there are two ways to query
the log data in Security Lake.
Either as data access,

where the data is ingested
by the third party solution,
or as query access,

where data is queried in
place in the Security Lake.
Splunk supports data access method,

which is configured by selecting
S3 for data access method.
As a security best practice,

it is important to use
account-level isolation

and set up Splunk solution
in an account other

than the account with
the security data lake.

For more details on
security best practices,
please look up the AWS security reference
architecture white paper.

Add an external ID to configure
secure access to the data

through AWS Identity and
Access Management Service,
avoiding the confused deputy problem.
According to the Splunk documentation

on configuring the
Security Lake subscriber,

the notification settings
should be set to SQS queue.
Select Create.

This should create the
subscriber configuration
in Security Lake for you.

Navigate to the Amazon
Simple Queue Service

or Amazon SQS to verify
the subscription endpoint.

Now that the subscriber
has been configured
at the Security Lake end,
you need to modify IAM policies

to make the Amazon
Security Lake add-on work.

Refer to the Splunk add-on
for AWS documentation.
Once you have configured the IAM policies,
navigate to the Splunkweb homepage
and configure a Splunk add-on for AWS.

Depending on the type
of Splunk deployment,
configure the AWS account setting
for your Splunk deployment.

Now that you have configured
the Splunk add-on for AWS,

you can query the log data
coming through to Splunk
from Security Lake.
In this demo,
I have shown you how you can configure
the Splunk add-on for Security Lake
to query data through Splunk.

It is important to
configure lease privilege
when configuring the integration,

and please refer to the
Splunk and AWS documentations.

For examples of configuring
restrictive IAM policies.
There are many different partners

that you can choose to
integrate with Security Lake,
so make sure you consult
the Amazon Security Lake documentation

to configure integration
with partner solutions.
Thank you for your time today.
